description: An examination of the language of Homer, an artificial mixture of dialectal and diachronic variants, a Kunstsprache . Against the background of a study of the comparative and historical grammar of Greek and its development from Proto‑Indo‑European, the focus is on diachronic aspects of Homeric grammar and diction. Readings are principally from Books One and Three of the Iliad .

name: Archaic Latin and the Italic Dialects
description: A study of inscriptions in archaic Latin and the ancient Italic dialects Oscan and Umbrian. Examination of the main features of phonology, morphology, syntax and the lexicon which distinguish Osco‑Umbrian from Latin, with reference to their development from Proto‑Indo‑European.

name: Hittite
description: The fundamentals of Hittite grammar are presented through the extensive reading of texts, both in transliteration and cuneiform. Considerable attention is given to problems of comparative grammar.

name: Advanced Semantics
description: This course provides students with the opportunity to study a topic of individual interest under the guidance of a faculty member.
antirequisite: Students who have received credit for this topic under a LING 429 number may not take this course for credit.

name: Advanced Topics in Linguistics
description: Specific topics for this course, and prerequisites relevant in each case, are stated in the Undergraduate Class Schedule. NON-PROGRAM COURSES: Hebrew THE DEPARTMENT RESERVES THE RIGHT TO TRANSFER A STUDENT TO A HIGHER‑LEVEL LANGUAGE COURSE IF IT IS DEEMED THAT THE COURSE FOR WHICH THE STUDENT HAS REGISTERED IS NOT APPROPRIATE FOR THE EXTENT OF HIS OR HER KNOWLEDGE OF THE LANGUAGE.

name: Introductory Course in Hebrew
description: This course continues the comprehensive review of Hebrew grammar and syntax, and deals with additional details not covered in the introductory course. Practice is provided through compositions and readings of classical and modern Hebrew texts.
prerequisite: HEBR 241 or permission of the Department
antirequisite: Students who have received credit for HEBR 250 may not take this course for credit.

name: Topics in Hebrew Literature
description: Topics for this course will vary; possibilities may include modern Hebrew literature, masterpieces and genres in Hebrew literature, and others. This course is taught in English. Modern Languages The following courses give instruction in languages and cultures not included in any of the Department’s programs.

name: Modern Greek
description: This course provides an introduction to the basic elements of modern Greek for the student with no knowledge of the language.
antirequisite: Students who have received credit for this topic under an MODL 399 number may not take this course for credit.

name: Special Topics in Modern Greek
description: Specific topics for this course, and prerequisites relevant in each case, are stated in the Undergraduate Class Schedule.

name: Modern Irish
description: This course provides an introduction to the basic elements of modern Irish for the student with no knowledge of the language.
antirequisite: Students who have received credit for this topic under an MODL 399 number may not take this course for credit.

name: Special Topics in Modern Irish
description: Specific topics for this course, and prerequisites relevant in each case, are stated in the Undergraduate Class Schedule.

name: Special Topics in Modern Languages
description: Specific topics for these courses, and prerequisites relevant in each case, are stated in the Undergraduate Class Schedule.

name: Special Topics in Modern Languages
description: Specific topics for these courses, and prerequisites relevant in each case, are stated in the Undergraduate Class Schedule.

name: Advanced Topics in Modern Languages
description: Specific topics for these courses, and prerequisites relevant in each case, are stated in the Undergraduate Class Schedule.

name: Russian
description: This course provides an introduction to the basic elements of Russian for the student with no knowledge of the language.
antirequisite: Students who have received credit for RUSS 330 may not take this course for credit.

name: Special Topics in Russian
description: Specific topics for this course, and prerequisites relevant in each case, are stated in the Undergraduate Class Schedule. 2020-2021 Concordia University Undergraduate Calendar
